E.P.A. Proposes Changes In Regulating Carcinogens The Environmental Protection Agency is proposing major changes in how it determines which chemicals and pollutants cause cancer, relying less on animal tests and more on new techniques of microbiology.

The changes, backed by both industry and scientists, are expected to have profound effects on regulating pesticides, methods for treating municipal drinking water, limits on factories' emissions and standards for cleaning up toxic waste. [Page A1.]

Dole Helps Ethanol Industry The ethanol industry, thanks largely to Senator Bob Dole, remains one of the most subsidized American industries. Mr. Dole cites protection of Midwestern farmers and the need for clean-burning, renewable energy sources, but his action has also helped his biggest financial patron, Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland. [A1.]

Dow Surges 60.33 Points Stocks soared in reaction to higher-than-expected corporate earnings and a rising bond market. The Dow industrials surged 60.33 points, to 5,592.92, while the Nasdaq composite rose 9.50, to 1,110.44. [D10.]

G.M. Troubled By Ohio Strike A wildcat strike in Lordstown, Ohio, shut down a plant that makes some of General Motors' most popular cars, including the Chevrolet Cavaliers and Pontiac Sunfires, the latest sign of labor unrest at the world's largest auto maker. [D7.]
Texas Utilities to Buy Enserch Texas Utilities agreed to acquire Enserch, owner of Lone Star Gas and Lone Star Pipeline, in a deal valued at $1.7 billion. [D2.]
An Acquisition in Data Security RSA Data Security, which makes software for cryptography, agreed to be acquired by Security Dynamics Technologies for stock worth $251 million. [D8.]
Cheyenne Software rejected an unsolicited $1 billion takeover bid from a rival, McAfee Associates, as inadequate. [D8.]

U.S. Warns China of Sanctions The Clinton Administration is said to have warned Chinese leaders that failure to comply with a 1995 agreement protecting copyrighted American products from piracy could result in sanctions on $2 billion of imports. [D4.]

Travelers Gains, Thanks to Broker Travelers Group said its earnings jumped 42 percent, to $520.2 million, or $1.55 a share -- well above forecasts -- in the first quarter, as profits more than doubled at its brokerage unit, Smith Barney. [D3.]
Other brokers' profits were also strong. Merrill Lynch posted a 79.4 percent gain, and Paine Webber's earnings nearly tripled. [D3.]
A Key Resignation at Apple Apple Computer's top executive for research and development, David C. Nagel, is leaving after eight years with the company to head the newly formed AT&T Laboratories. [D2.]

Utilities Face Nuclear Costs Holders of utility stocks, already skittish from cuts in dividends and drives to make electricity pricing more competitive, can now begin to worry about what the industry calls stranded costs, generally the cost overruns on nuclear plants. Market Place. [D10.]

Kennedy's Anti-Layoff Bill Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced tax legislation intended to discourage layoffs resulting from corporate mergers. The bill would disallow tax deductions for interest paid to finance mergers and acquisitions. [A18.]
